title: SCRUM'S THE WORD: England train in boggy conditions in Yokohama
text:
A miniature moat formed around the edge of the pitch before England’s captain’s run in Yokohama on Friday. Heavy rainfall in the morning turned the pitch into a bog.

England coach Scott Wisemantel took the chance to have a water fight with one of the backroom staff. The rain is expected to ease before Saturday’s game and organisers are confident in the stadium’s drainage systems.

England trained in boggy conditions during the captain's run in Yokohama on Friday

The rain is due to ease and organisers are confident in the stadium's drainage system

Not even Warren Gatland could hold his poker face when asked about goings on back in his hometown of Hamilton, New Zealand.

A reporter from the area asked: ‘Warren, we’re used to seeing you back home walking around Hamilton, watching the cricket. How much more enjoyable would that be with the World Cup?’

Gatland laughed, before saying: ‘I’m not sure the WRU would let me take the World Cup back to New Zealand.’

The Japan Rugby Football Union have opened talks with head coach Jamie Joseph about a new contract.

Joseph’s team inspired the nation with their run to the quarter-finals and the coach has been linked with a return to New Zealand. JRFU president Shigetaka Mori said: ‘The selection committee has decided to ask him to continue as head coach.’

Japanese rugby chiefs are looking to tie head coach Jamie Joseph down to an extended deal

If Wales lose to South Africa tomorrow, their CEO Martyn Phillips will not hang around for the third-place play-off on Friday.

Phillips — who came to Japan in light of the Rob Howley departure, then went home only to return to Japan two weeks later — will fly home once again. He’ll be doing well for Air Miles.

Despite only arriving home from the World Cup last week, Scotland star Stuart Hogg is ready to make his Exeter debut against Bath today.

The full back was on the verge of tears after defeat by the Brave Blossoms, but there was little sympathy from Hogg’s new Chiefs team-mates who jokingly surrounded his place in the Sandy Park changing room with Japanese flags.
description: NIK SIMON: England coach Scott Wisemantel took the chance to have a water fight with one of the backroom staff. The rain is expected to ease before Saturday's game against New Zealand.
authors: Nik Simon For The Daily Mail
